definition: A specific commercial enterprise or establishment.
(chiefly British) An area of land; a district, region.
Buying and selling of goods and services on a market.
Physical motion between points in space.
A journey through a particular building, estate, country, etc.
An act of transporting; conveyance.
The act of moving; a movement.
The act of transporting, or the state of being transported; conveyance, often of people, goods etc.
Motivation to do or achieve something; ability coupled with ambition.
A proposal that has been made.
A set amount of travelling, seen as a single unit; a discrete trip, a voyage.
Any insect of the order Diptera; characterized by having two wings (except for some wingless species), also called true flies.
A journey; an excursion or jaunt
The act of travelling or sightseeing, particularly away from one's home.
Someone who travels for pleasure rather than for business.
The encountering of risks; a bold undertaking, in which dangers are likely to be encountered, and the issue is staked upon unforeseen events; a daring feat.
A journey through a particular building, estate, country, etc.
The process of exploring.
A long journey, especially by ship.
A sea or lake voyage, especially one taken for pleasure.
Someone who travels for pleasure rather than for business.
The act of flying.
An official document normally used for international journeys, which proves the identity and nationality of the person for whom it was issued.
Freedom provided by the cessation of activities.
A permit to enter and leave a country, normally issued by the authorities of the country to be visited.
(usually a mass noun) Lodging in a dwelling or similar living quarters afforded to travellers in hotels or on cruise ships, or prisoners, etc.
Freedom from some business or activity.
A company that flies airplanes to transport people and goods.
A journey made to a sacred place, or a religious journey.
A journey by ox wagon.
An extended adventurous voyage.
To live in a tent or similar temporary accommodation.
To exchange substantially; to abate but not abolish completely, a penalty, obligation, or payment in return for a great, single thing or an aggregate; to cash in; to lessen
A convoy or procession of travelers, their vehicles and cargo, and any pack animals, especially camels crossing a desert.
A member of a particular nomadic ethnic minority in Ireland, the Pavee.
One who travels, especially on a journey to visit sites of religious significance.
A cosmopolitan person; a cosmopolite.
A member of a particular nomadic ethnic minority in Ireland, the Pavee.
A long journey, especially by ship.
A brief recreational trip; a journey out of the usual way.
To exchange substantially; to abate but not abolish completely, a penalty, obligation, or payment in return for a great, single thing or an aggregate; to cash in; to lessen
The act or instance of wandering.
One who wanders, who travels aimlessly.
The peregrine falcon.
To wander or travel freely and with no specific destination.
One who travels from place to place.
A person on a trip of indeterminate destination and/or length of time.
Directed backwards, retreating; reverting, especially to an inferior state, declining; inverse, reverse; movement opposite to normal or intended motion, often circular motion.
The act of circumnavigating, or sailing round.
To hike and camp overnight in backcountry with one's gear carried in a backpack
A strong impulse or longing to travel.
To maneuver around and behind the flank of (an opposing force).
One who goes sightseeing; one who goes around to look at sights or see things of interest; a tourist.
A low bed on wheels that can be rolled underneath another bed.
A physical condition caused by crossing time zones during flight; often the result of disruption to the circadian rhythms of the body.
A limestone rubble.
A wearisome journey.
To travel; make a journey.
One who treks; thus, a hiker.
(of time) To pass or move by.
One who travels together with another.
A travel or journey, especially by foot, notably by a pilgrim.
(heading) Employment.
To move or travel (from one location to another).
To be alive; to have life.
Any solid substance that can be consumed by living organisms, especially by eating, in order to sustain life.
The inevitable progression into the future with the passing of present and past events.
To travel from place to place, especially to preach or lecture.
To eat; to eat dinner or supper.
To travel from place to place, or from one country to another, especially on foot; hence, to sojourn in foreign countries.
A large town house or mansion; a grand private residence, especially in France.
The capacity, condition, or state of acting or of exerting power.
The amount of space between two points, usually geographical points, usually (but not necessarily) measured along a straight line.
A style of living that reflects the attitudes and values of a person or group.
A group of people who are closely related to one another (by blood, marriage or adoption); kin; for example, a set of parents and their children; an immediate family.
An outdoor place acting as temporary accommodation in tents or other temporary structures.
An advertisement by which individuals attempt to meet others with similar interests.
The fact or act of surviving; continued existence or life.
The state of being free from physical or psychological disease, illness, or malfunction; wellness.
A junketer.
An opportunity to test something out; a test.
The act or service of welcoming, receiving, hosting, or entertaining guests.
To change place or posture; to go, in any manner, from one place or position to another.
The act of immigrating; the passing or coming into a country of which one is not native born for the purpose of permanent residence.
Amusement, enjoyment or pleasure
A dwelling.
